div1.p: Hench poses questions regarding the yellow fever experiments because he knows that Kean had connections with Reed.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, January 12, 1941
div1.opener:
Letter begun
Sunday, January 12, 1941
My dear General Kean:
div1.p:
I have at last been able to finish and send off an 18 page single spaced
typewritten letter of comments and suggestions re Gen. Truby's manuscript. Because
you two have collaborated so often and because I am quoting you frequently in my
letter to him, I am herewith sending you a carbon copy of it, and have told Gen.
Truby that I was doing so. I am sure he would not object. I want to be sure I
am quoting you correctly, and also it is likely that you may be able to answer
some of the questions I have asked him which he might not be able to answer.

In particular I'd like your reaction to my argument that Agramonte had
more to do with the affair than Truby believes. Also will you kindly note especially
the following comments (numbered in my letter to Gen. Truby): 1-8-13-22-23-24-26-32-
35-44-45-50-52-59-61-62-63. In reference to my comment 44 could you tell me who
Dr. Echevarria was, his rank and job and how it happened that he mediated with Dr.
Rojas in the leasing of the San Jose Farm for the site of Camp Lazear?

I enclose one of the photos which Miss Agramonte found and which she is
anxious to have identified as to site. Do you recognize the little building?

I hope you received the W. and J. booklet with the various talks therein.
I was entirely unaware that they were publishing mine. Dr. Hutchison had previously
told me they had no place to publish it and it suited my purpose better anyhow to
reserve it for medical literature. Hence I was surprised to see it published in the
brochure sent out to alumni and friends of W. and J. I wasn't sent any proof--hence
had no chance to out out the expression which you found objectionable (re Finley
being slightly “touched”, an expression I copied from his son's own book). Nor did
I have a chance to correct one or two other misspelled words (they had epidemiologic
spelled wrong, also Pogolotti's name was missppelled). Also the data of Lazear's
illness should have been Sept 16, not Aug 16.

Now permit me to send you some belated comments on your most interesting
and valuable diary. As I read it I jotted down items therein which I thought it would
be helpful for me to know. Let me number my comments and refer to the dates in
your diary.

item.p:
1. Aug. 14, 1898. You were “relieved as medical inspector of the Second
Division” by being put in charge of the hospital at Camp Cuba Libre, Jacksonville,
Florida. What was the name of the hospital and your rank and title?

For Keans additional answers see his long letter
of Jan 23, 1941

list.item:
2. Aug. 26, 1898 (addendum). You met the famous Typhoid Fever Board --
Reed, Vaughan and Shakespeare. Had you met Reed before? What was he like then?

3. Fri. Jan. 6, 1899. What hospitals do you mean referring to those where
Jackson worked and McDill erected? 1st Division Hospital 7th Army Corps
interests
4. Jan. 26, 1899. Was this the first case of yellow fever you ever saw? Yes

item.p:
5. Feb. 7, 1899. You mention Military Hospital #2, Vedado. I was con-
fused by the photographs of “Military Hospital #1” in the various “Reports of and to
the Surgeon General”. Please see comment #13 of my letter to Gen. Truby. Can you
help me out?

My recollection is that Military Hospital No. 1.
was the Spanish Army Hospital in Havana called Alfonso Treci
(XIII)

list.item:
#2.
No I think not

6. Feb. 25, 1899. You mention receiving a letter from Reed. Do you
have this and other letters from Reed or other members of the Board? I would give
a great deal to see them or be allowed to photostat and study them at leisure. It
is amazing how much help I have already gotten about disputed points by being allowed
to study a very few letters of Lazear (loaned me by Mrs. Lazear), Carroll (as published
by Hemmeter in Janus, 1908) and a couple of Reed letters I've seen (yours and one of
Gen. Truby). I strongly suspect you would hate to lend them to me even via the little
tin box. Would it be possible to have them photostated for me (and for yourself) in
the Surgeon General's office? I'd be willing to pay the cost if it weren't too much.
If this isn't possible perhaps I may see them in your home sometime. Where was Reed
when he wrote you the letter noted on this date?

7. Apr. 11, 1899. He was still in his tent in Cause at Buena Vista
I am not sure where the headquarters of Gen. Lee were
at this time. Were they in the building on Real St. which I visited and photograph? see it below
Where did you live and eat? Why was Gen. Lee street named after Gen. Lee when his
headquarters were on Real Street eventually? I do not know date in March or April I think
I lived & kept house at 27 Gen. Lee St. until Nov. 29, 1899. Then Major Edmunds took the
house & died there of y. f.

8. May 4, 1899. “Today Reed came out to lunch.” What was he doing in
Cuba then? He had been sent to Cuba to investigate an outbreak of
typhoid fever at Puerto Principe in east Cuba

9. May 10, 1899. You mention the “Toledo House”. Is that the house on
Real Street I noted in #6? You mean #7- Yes-
Probably news published - said all

10. May 26, 1899. Where is Reed's report published and what did it
concern? The cases were typhoid not malaria or yellow fever- Reed was
sent down from wash to see- see my memo attached as to Reed's visits to Cuba-

11. June 7, 1899. You wrote to Reed, Where was he, in Washington? Yes
I find no reason in doing of writting to Reed on June 7- He was of want

item.p:
12. July 17, 1899. In your published papers and in the margined note
beside the entry of July 1, 1900 you say that when Reed called to see you sick of
yellow fever June 25, 1900 yours was the “first case of yellow fever” that Reed ever
saw. But here in your entry of July 17, 1899 you note that Reed who was again in
Cuba (doing what?) called you to the hospital (what hospital?) to see a post-mortem
on a case of yellow fever. Apparently he had seen posts of yellow fever cases before
seeing you as the first living patient (?) with yellow fever. Is this so?

That not not Major Walter Reed but Capt. Reed who showed me the yellow fever
case
at Post Hospital

list.item:
13. Aug. 2, 1899. What was Dr. Carter doing in Cuba? Is the correct
spelling “doherty” as you have it or as Gen. Truby called it “Dougherty wagons of
Indian days”? Speaking of this I understand Reed drove from Camp Columbia to Camp
Lazear generally twice daily in a doherty wagon. Is that correct so far as you
know? Of course that would only take about 15-20 minutes each way, but I under-
stand you all often rode to Havana and back that way. It was a long, tiresome ride,
wasn't it, being 9 kilometers from Havana to Quemados.

14. Aug. 18, 1899. Where were you living in Quemados on this date?
27 Gen Lee street or Cavojal St. as it was called then

15. Sept. 10, 1899. The Carter mentioned here was not Dr. Henry
Carter, I believe. No Major Wm Fitzhugh Carter was in Med Corps of Army- He was a cousin
of Dr. Henry Rose Carter of the Marine Hospital Service now the Public Health Service

16. Sept. 13, 1899. Where was Dr. Ducker's “yellow fever hospital”? It was
a small affair outside Havana in Gorgas's department- He was not in the Med Corps of Army

17. Dec. 3, 1899. You mention Gen. Lee's house in Maceo Street where
you also lived. How many headquarters did he move into? He had only one Headquarters
in Marianao after he left the camp- It was the big house on the Calzada Real
which you know - the house in Maceo St. he rented for his family when they
came down- The Hdqrs moved into the big house on the Calzada (Toledo House)
on May 13th see p 115 of diary as I moved into the house on Maceo St. Nov. 29
& the Lee family on Dec. 2 1899- When they went to U.S. May 17, 1899- Gen. Lee
and I then moved over to the Hdqrs at the Casa Toledo & Took bedrooms upstairs-

The plan for Reed to go to the Philippines was given up-
I do not know who planned it or why it was abandoned- Gen Sternberg
was a long student of yellow fever and greatly interested in it- He and
Reed were the highest authorities on preventive medicine in the Army-
Such a high authority as Victor C. Vaughan of Aun Arbor was willing 3. to serve
under Reed on the Typhoid Board.

18. Dec. 15, 1899. You had a letter from Reed. Where from? You say
he expected to go to Philippines and then “return next November to Cuba to tackle
yellow fever.” I have never seen this statement before. It infers that it was
Reed's original idea and not Sternberg's to do the yellow fever work. Is this
correct? I gather that Reed was sort of a bacteriologic “trouble-shooter” for the
U.S. Army Medical Corps. He was-

19. Mar. 10, 1900. Reed was in Cuba. Howawas that, see above did he go and return
from the Philippines so quickly? I undertand he came to Cuba to study electrozone.

Reed came to Havana to determine the bacteriocidal value of electrozone March
10-1900
I have us record when he left but his stay was short, not over 2 weeks. I think-

20 May 27, 1900. You note the outbreak of yellow fever at 20 Gen. Lee
St. and (in your entry of June 8) it spread to 102 Real St. Please see my comment
#23 in my letter to Gen. Truby. Reed was in error in stating the spread the other
way about, wasn't he? Reed wasn't yet in Havana; he got this data from whom? from
you? Where were the “isolation wards” to which King was taken?

21. June 8, 1900. Please orient me as to the addresses of the victims
listed here. I gather that cases 1-5 lived at 20 Gen. Lee St. What was the name
and address of case 6? I can't make it out. Where did case 7 (Ballentino) live?
102 Real St.? Apparently cases 7 and 8 lived at 102 Real and cases 9-10- and 11 lived
at 89 Real St. was it case 12 Hamberger or case 13 Schenck who lived at 102 Real?
Where were you living at this time? I am interested in trying to check the spread of
the disease as given by you with the comments in Dr. Angles' letter (see enclosed.
I believe I sent you one before; please return this one). I am glad to have received
your correction of Dr. Angles' letter that it was Major and Mrs. Edmunds and not you and
Mrs. Kean who got sick at #20 Gen. Lee St.

22. In your entry of June 14, 1900 you mention Carter H. C. Does this
mean Dr. Henry Rose Carter; does the H. C. mean “hospital corp”? The story you told
me about your secret visit to the front porch of Major Edmund's house was such an
interesting human one, illustrating a conflict between the military man in you (ordered
to keep away from the major) and the humans physician who scorned self-quarantine.
I'd appreciate it very much if you'd be willing to write this out in detail and permit
me to use it sometime. Surely it can do no harm and it redounds to your credit as
a physician.

23. July 1, 1900. Do you have any recollection of Reed's visit to you on
June 25, conversation, etc.? I'd like very much to use later (in my monograph) what-
ever details you can give me. It is very interesting to think that Reed saw you under
these circumstances his first day on his mission. Where were you cared for?

24. Sept. 1, 1900. You lived at Columbia Barracks. I have found no
photos of the Barracks except the one of the model of the Post Hospital and another
one Kissinger gave me but none of the rest of the barracks. When, where and why did
Godfrey commit suicide? Should this incident be kept hidden or is it generally known?

25. Sept. 3, 1900. How soon did you know the source of Carroll's illness,
and of Dean's? Do we have the right to conclude from the letters of Lazear to Mrs.
L., and from Agramonte's twice-stated remarks that the first one or two cases were
produced by Lazear “unknown to his colleagues”) that Carroll had no expectation of
becoming ill? How soon after Dean's illness did you learn the facts from Lazear or
others? (I believe you wrote me this before.)

26. Sept. 25. Your personal version of Lazear's death would be most
interesting. When did you first hear that perhaps he had died from deliberate
infection?

27. Oct. 7, 1900. When did you add the question mark at the end of
your sentence “This probably caused his death(?).”

28. Oct. 13, 1900. You have described briefly in print your visit with
Reed to see Gen. Wood but can you not amplify your written description? This visit
was of considerable historical interest and I'd like much to use an amplification
of your story.

29. Oct. 20, 1900. In my short story and monograph would it be permissible
to use the names of Major and Mrs. Peterson, of Major Cartwright, Edmunds, etc.? I
believe they have been used in stories already published.

30. In the notes on the back page of your diary you stated "Reed returned
to Washington, Feb. 7-10, 1901. What do these 2 dates mean?

¶31 I am sure I will learn much and will certainly enjoy reading such data as
you will let me have from subsequent diaries. Being as intimately connected with
Reed you must recall many data that have never been published. I would very much
like to have a generous amount of “General Kean data” in any monograph I ever write.
You have been too modest and I hope your wife will “take my side” and encourage you
to be less “modest” and let me have more of your own personal information and ideas.

¶32 When you met Moran in Charlottesville did he have time to tell you of our
(and his) investigations re Bldg. #1? How did they sound? Please tell me if you
think we are right or are you skeptical? Have you any comments re my plan to
memorialize it? I will go to Cuba in March, satisfy myself fully and then act
accordingly, getting a deed, seeing Sec. Ramos as to how my ideas will best fit
into his plans, etc. If it is necessary for me to do so (i.e. if I can't raise the
money among a dozen friends) would you approve the idea of my forming an advisory
committee to investigate our data, approve our findings and aims and lend their
names on a letter to be sent to interested (?) institutions, etc. I should like you,
Gen. Truby, perhaps Gen. Reed and others.

¶33 Let me now refer to some of our recent correspondence. In your letter of
October 9 to me you noted the “violent attack on the scheme published in the Havana
newspaper La Lucha.” Do you know the approximate date of this attack? I spent
several hours in the New York Public Library trying to find it in their copies of
La Lucha but I couldn't locate it in Spanish. I suspect I was looking at the wrong
file as their files were incomplete.

¶34 Have you ever seen Hemmeter's article in Janus (Vol. 13, 1908, pp. 57-72
and 150-176) in which he gives practically all the credit to Carroll as the real
master mind? The article contains many letters from Carroll to his wife. Some of
them make rather strange reading. It is difficult to understand how he could
so casually dismiss Lazear's death in his letter of Sept. 26 (the date must have
been printed wrong; it was presumably written the day Lazear died which was Sept. 25).
#5.
His letter of Nov. 25, 1900 referring to a party given by Mrs. Kean is rather
“sticky”. Without meaning to detract from the honor of your friendship I do not
react well to Carroll's gloating over the fact that you actually sat with your arm
on the back of his chair! That doesn't strike me as being a normal male's reaction
or that of a true scientific extrovert. But I suppose one must discount such reactions
as mine because after all one's personal letters to one's wife would probably always
look queer in cold print.

¶35 May I ask especially about his letter of Dec. 30, 1900. He wrote, “I
went to the city yesterday and drew $950 from the bank to pay the men upon whom we
have experimented. Out of that I paid $129.00 for a watch chain and charm to be
presented to one of these men for his courage in submitting to the inoculation....”
Is this true? Did he do that? I suppose he did it on orders from Reed or from you
as disbursing officer but he (Carroll) (or at least Hemmeter, the author) gives the
impression that Carroll was in charge of more or less everything, the disbursements,
handing out of largesse, etc.

¶36 Notice an additional error. The letter on page 161 dated Aug. 27, 1900
was not written in 1900, of course, but in 1901.

¶37 [Why so many errors as to the date of Lazear's death? The clinical
records clearly show that he died Sept. 25 but the date is given as Sept. 28 in at
least 3 places: in Carroll's letter quoted above; in Kelly's book, first edition,
page 271 (and presumably on the bronze tablet at Hopkins!), and on the temporary
memorial tablet erected at Las Animas Hospital; I hope they don't perpetuate the
mistake in final bronze!]

¶38 Have you been able to find the “little bundle of retained papers”? I
only wish I could help by putting on old clothes with you and searching. It would
be a real treasure hunt. If you find one of the contracts I would be more than glad
and proud to have it, I assure you.

¶39 I think it would be fine if you could write Dr. Angles and straighten
him out. It might make my March visit much more profitable and easy. Also a letter
to Secretary Ramos (whom you have met) would do wonders in preparing him to receive
me again. His address Dr. Domingo Ramos, (His Excellency, etc.), Secretary for
Defense, Havana, etc. Also if Dr. Albertini knew you were sympathetic with my
investigations I know my mission would be much easier and more successful.

¶40 I shudder when I think how much work I am asking you to undertake in
looking over all these notes and answering so many questions, especially if you persist
in answering in long hand. I would be so glad to help you locate a stenographer and
pay for her services in taking down your answers and thoughts as you may dictate them
to her in as much detail as possible. My only defense in asking so much of you is
that I know you are much more interested in the perpetuation of the truth about all
this even than I am. The only way I can show you my appreciation is to use the
material you send me as honestly and faithfully as I can. This I promise to do.

div1.p:
Mrs. Hench and I were very pleased to receive your Christmas card.
We thought the little snapshot of you and Mrs. Kean with the two faithful servants
hovering nearby was so nice.
div1.closer: Very sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
